awd_abstract_narration: Emerging computational RFID (Radio Frequency IDentification) tags combine sensing and computation with traditional RFID technology. The combination allows small, long-lived sensors that are as unobtrusive as a sticker to be placed on everyday objects and read when they are in the proximity of an RFID reader.  The technology is an enabler for ubiquitous computing, cyber-physical systems, and sensor networks. This project is developing computational RFIDs as a networked system, with an emphasis on operating system software and hardware support on the computational RFID tags and network protocols that will support new applications. One key research challenge is that these devices are extremely energy limited and dependent on the varying energy they can harvest; the tags must schedule tasks well to use energy effectively. A second research challenge is to design network protocols that are well suited to computational RFID, since traditional RFID protocols are intended for repetitive inventorying tasks and sensor network protocols assume that nodes have symmetric abilities. The approach taken is experimental. The project is building software support and hardware extensions on an existing computational RFID tag, and prototyping candidate applications. The impacts of this research will be to extend the coverage with which computing systems can instrument the physical world, which in turn enables new applications, such as automated activity detection for eldercare, that are beneficial to society. The software and hardware developed as part of this project will be made available to other researchers and for educational use.

The major goal of the project is to develop innovative, small networked computing systems that run using the power that they harvest from RF signals put out by nearby infrastructure. This new kind of computer system does not exist yet, except in the nascent form as passive UHF RFID tags such as the EPC Gen 2 tags that are limited in their functionality and heavily specialized to inventorying applications.

 

To be useful, these new computers must be able to sense the environment, perform processing, and communicate with nearby infrastructure. All of these tasks are challenging given the scarcity of energy. Our vision is to take the best ideas from RFID to build more general sensing, computing and communication systems that work with ultra-low power for cyberphysical, ubiquitous computing and embedded systems. Our research is focused on strategies for gathering sensor data and communicating this data and other information between the RF-powered computers and nearby, powered infrastructure.

 

The network protocol design considerations for this new form of RF-powered computing covers all of the physical, link, network and application layers, with an emphasis on the physical and application layers. New strategies are required to work with the tiny energy levels that are available. The strategies include communicating analog data, communicating changes in sensor levels, and assigning persistent identifiers to computers to lower protocol overheads.

 

In all of our research thus far we have based our designs on the use of backscatter communication. Backscatter communication works by modulating the reflection of an incident signal instead of transmitting a new signal. This technique shifts the energy costs from the RF-powered sender to a remote and more powerful transmitter. It is especially beneficial in the domain of RF-powered computers because the power levels required to simply transmit a signal powerful enough to be received across a large room already exceed the available power level of RF harvesting.

 

Our research is experimental in nature. To facilitate it, we build on the WISP programmable RFID tag developed by Josh Smith and others. To test out networking designs, we are prototyping both the RF-powered computer and the powered infrastructure by repurposing RFID equipment and SDR platforms such as the USRP. We can then experiment with the designs in the lab, and in our RFID-equipped building.

 

We have experimentally demonstrated the effectiveness of our sensor hub approach at lowering the energy consumption of rich sensing applications on mobile phones. We prototyped a sensor hub based on an 8-bit Atmel AVR microcontroller plus accelerometer, gyro and other sensors. We connected this sensor hub via external USB to a Galaxy Nexus Android mobile phone. We then selected a set of five applications (pedometers, driving and sleeping apps) written by others to improve. To allow the applications to use the sensor hub, we use a custom taint-tracking system we developed to rewrite the application bytecode to our sensor hub API. Finally, we used trace-driven analysis and a Monsoon power monitor to measure the energy costs of using the applications. For 4 out of the 5 applications, our approach substantially reduced the energy costs. The average savings were 80%. We conclude that a sensor hub approach is valuable for running these type of rich, continuous sensing applications at low energy cost.
